<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>

It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of handle_req_footers_no_space:
```c
static void
handle_req_footers_no_space (struct MHD_Connection *c,
                             const char *add_footer,
                             size_t add_footer_size)
{
  (void) add_footer; (void) add_footer_size; /* Unused */
  mhd_assert (c->rq.have_chunked_upload);

  /* Footers should be optional */
  transmit_error_response_static (c,
                                  MHD_HTTP_REQUEST_HEADER_FIELDS_TOO_LARGE,
                                  ERR_MSG_REQUEST_FOOTER_TOO_BIG);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static void
handle_req_footers_no_space (struct MHD_Connection *c,
                             const char *add_footer,
                             size_t add_footer_size)
explanation: There is no direct self-call in this function body, so the only way Rule 17.2 could be violated here is via indirect recursion through functions invoked by this function. The (void) casts for add_footer and add_footer_size, the comment, and the direct access of c->rq.have_chunked_upload are not function calls and therefore cannot introduce recursion. The static qualification and the function signature themselves do not constitute a call. Thus the only fragments that merit investigation for possible indirect recursion are the calls to mhd_assert and transmit_error_response_static (and, if desired, the function definition to track call sites). Other lines do not call functions and can be excluded from recursion-focused investigation.
